s-1.ptxt: REPLACE TIMING CHAIN COVER OIL SEAL

s2.ptxt: Place the timing chain cover on wooden blocks.
Using a screwdriver with its tip taped, pry out the oil seal.
Using SST and a hammer, tap in a new oil seal until its surface is flush with the timing chain cover edge.

item.ptxt: Keep the lip free from foreign matter.
Do not tap the oil seal at an angle.

atten4.ptxt: When installing the crankshaft pulley, check the shape of the pulley. The correct pulley has a groove (See page ).

s2.ptxt: Apply a light coat of MP grease to the oil seal lip.
Place the oil seal retainer on wooden blocks.
Using a screwdriver with its tip taped and a hammer, tap out the oil seal.
Place the oil seal retainer on wooden blocks.
Using SST and a hammer, tap in the oil seal until its surface is flush with the oil seal retainer edge.

item.ptxt: Keep the lip free from foreign matter.
Do not tap the oil seal at an angle.

s2.ptxt: Heat the cylinder head to 80 to 100°C (176 to 212°F).
Place the cylinder head on wooden blocks.
Using SST and a hammer, tap out the guide bush.
Using a caliper gauge, measure the bush bore diameter of the cylinder head.
Select a new guide bush (STD or O/S 0.05).

If the bush bore diameter of the cylinder head is greater than 10.306 mm (0.4057 in.), machine the bush bore to the a diameter of 10.335 to 10.356 mm (0.4069 to 0.4077 in.) to install an O/S 0.05 valve guide bush.
If the bush bore diameter of the cylinder head is greater than 10.356 mm (0.4077 in.), replace the cylinder head.
Heat the cylinder head to 80 to 100°C (176 to 212°F).
Place the cylinder head on wooden blocks.
Using SST and a hammer, tap in a new valve guide bush to the specified protrusion height.
Using a sharp 5.5 mm reamer, ream the valve guide bush to obtain the standard specified clearance.
Heat the cylinder head to 80 to 100°C (176 to 212°F).
Place the cylinder head on wooden blocks.
Using SST and a hammer, tap out the guide bush.
Using a caliper gauge, measure the bush bore diameter of the cylinder head.
Select a new guide bush (STD or O/S 0.05).

If the bush bore diameter of the cylinder head is greater than 10.306 mm (0.4057 in.), machine the bush bore to a diameter of 10.335 to 10.356 mm (0.4069 to 0.4077 in.) to install an O/S 0.05 valve guide bush.
If the bush bore diameter of the cylinder head is greater than 10.356 mm (0.4077 in.), replace the cylinder head.
Heat the cylinder head to 80 to 100°C (176 to 212°F).
Place the cylinder head on wooden blocks.
Using SST and a hammer, tap in a new valve guide bush to the specified protrusion height.
Using a sharp 5.5 mm reamer, ream the valve guide bush to obtain the standard specified clearance.

s-1.ptxt: REPLACE CONNECTING ROD SMALL END BUSH

s2.ptxt: Using SST and a press, press out the bush.
Align the oil holes of a new bush and the connecting rod.
Using SST and a press, press in the bush.
Using a pin hole grinder, hone the bush to obtain the standard specified clearance between the bush and piston pin.
Check that the piston pin fits at normal room temperature.

s3.ptxt: Coat the piston pin with engine oil, and push it into the connecting rod with your thumb.
